This is a brilliant museum well worth the visit.  I was largely ignorant about this Solidarity movement, I had heard of Lech Walesa, he is something of a hero in Poland. We were given head sets and were able to listen a commentary as we went. You can tell the museum is relatively new, but it is absolutely fascinating what you learn and read up about. We also took in the rooftop experience which is quite something, the views are really good.

The building alone is well worth the visit, the building is designed to resemble the hulk of a ship under construction and looks incredible. Inside you have a central atrium leading to the permanent exhibition, cafe, shop, office space and rooftop viewing area. The exhibition takes you on a journey through soviet rule, strikes, the solidarity movement, martial law and eventual freedom. It is an excellent exhibition using original artifacts and modern technology. Don't miss it if you are in Gdansk.

Maybe if I was Polish/had been aware of world politics in the 80s, this would have been interesting. The way it is, I feel they spent a lot of money (and curated a great modern multimedia exhibition) around very little content. I'm German, born in the mid 80s and have a history degree (so not averse to reading all the small boring print) but the entire exhibition felt out of context to me. What led to the events? What was life like in communist Poland? Why was the shipyard so damn important? The only interesting part was the second to last room that compares the situation in all the countries of the Eastern bloc. The audio guide was super frustrating and not keeping up with my movements. I took the 2.5 tour and was done with the place after just over an hour. Definitely could have skipped this and spent more time at other museums in town instead.

Tl;dr: This is not a museum with an audio guide, this is an audio guide with a museum. And should be probably marketed as such.

One of those modern museums which look all shiny and cool but then you enter the first room and you are like whaaat is this about exactly?

I had a vague idea of Solidarity, hoping the museum would provide me with some big picture and more context... Instead I felt overwhelmed with random fractions of information and unimportant details.

There was a total lack of information hierarchy and storytelling. I used ChatGpt to make at least some basic sense of the whole thing... and then ended up reading the Wikipedia page anyway, skipping most of the exhibition.

Having read other reviews, the mistake I made was not taking the audio guide. I can't testify whether it'd really make that much of a difference but for sure it doesn't make any sense to enter the museum without the guide.

Personally, I prefer museums that can function on their own, even without an audio guide.

SOLIDARNOST (Solidarity) - a very powerful, emotional and meaningful word in Poland. And, for a good reason.

I must admit despite excellent reviews I entered the museum with low expectations. Coming from a similar country I knew pretty much about the events that initiated changes in eastern Europe. However, after the first 15 min I was blown away and enjoyed the rest of my visit to maximum.

Museum is located north from old town Gdansk, just aside the entrance to the shipyard where it all began.
In front of it is a monument of 3 huge crosses with anchors on top of them to commemorate the victims of the first strike from Dec 1970. Interesting fact is that it was erected in 1980, still during communist oppression, and therefore is considered first such monument built during communist regime, but when Solidarnost gained some rights.
Museum architecture is amazing - ultra modern edifice with rust like modern facade resembling ship's body. Interior is a huge atrium like open space with glass and greenery resembling freedom.
From there, excellent audio guide takes you on a tour through several levels.
I rarely take audio guides as they're sometimes boring, with unnecessary facts and sometimes difficult to understand.
This one is state of the art - you don't need to do anything. It automatically tells you stories (easy understanding and with interesting and important facts) depending on your position where you are, and tells you the way you should go.

Apart from the audio guide, there are so many interesting exhibits, short movies, hands-on displays, articles from newspapers, pictures, personal items,....

If you have any interest in that part of Europe history, I strongly advise you to visit this museum. Count on around 2 hours for a proper visit.

Congratulations Poles on your will and strength to fight communism oppression and big respect to SOLIDARNOST

Today I wanted to introduce my 5 years old son to the history and heritage of SolidarnoÅ›Ä‡ and I failed completely.

The European Solidarity Centre in GdaÅ„sk is a beacon of historical remembrance and contemporary enlightenment. Its extensive exhibitions transport you back in time, providing a profound insight into the Solidarity Movement. The architecture is a symbol of industrial heritage, while the green rooftop symbolizes hope. Each corner tells a story of resilience, making it a riveting, educational journey. The staff's dedication enriches the experience, making it a must-visit epitome of Poland's enduring spirit.

Excellent presentation of the whole scenario surrounding the rise of Solidarity union and the subsequent eventual collapse of communism in Europe. Gave the big picture as well as the more detailed information on the major players.

I don't quite understand why the gentleman at the ticket office told me that ticket sales ended an hour ago when we arrived at 5 p.m. and the museum is open until 7 p.m.  So we lost the opportunity to see the exhibition.  At least we took the elevator to the observation deck.

A must see when in Gdansk, such an important piece of history and a great reminder of modern times!
The headphones are a bit annoying (huge &flimsy), but the audio guide was brilliant and the exhibits are very creatively placed. Lots of different objects (pieces of clothing, lockers, posters, cars, photos, videos, cartoons). The museumâ€™s interior and exterior is impressive as well and bears symbolism. We decided to take the shorter audio guide (1,5 hour) and we felt it was plenty for us; it helped us skip a few exhibits, but the storyline was still solid. You can take a longer one that probably would tell you a lot more about all the exhibits.
Absolutely recommend!

Absolutely fantastic museum, a must-see in Gdansk. It explains the struggle during the communist era and the transition to democracy, with the focus in the Solidarity movement. It has great features, like the 70s style apartment, the Police riot truck or the interrogation room. The architecture, inside and outside the building is also very nice. One of the best and most interesting museums I have ever visited.
Dobra lekcja powojennej historii

Zeer indrukwekkend museum dat het verhaal van de opkomst van Solidaridat en Lech Walesa weergeeft. Veel verhalen van de opkomst waren mij bekend maar zeker ook de onderdrukking en gruwelijkheden van het communistische regime worden op treffende wijze duidelijk gemaakt. Zeker in het huidige tijdsbeeld geeft dit inzichten in hoe het in het Rusland moet zijn. Via mooie foto's, videobeelden en displays wordt de geschiedenis prachtig in beeld gebracht. Onderschrift is gelukkig ook in het Engels. De duidelijkheid van de audiotour maakt het compleet. Een absolute must see wanneer je in Gdansk bent.

Hands down, one of the best museums I have ever had the chance to visit!
Housed in a modern architectural building, it welcomes its visitors to take an insightful journey of "SolidarnosÃ©", a Polish trade union formed at the Gdansk Shipyard, in 1980; it became a major social movement, advocating for workers' rights and social change and was led by Lech Walesa; this movement resulted in the 1989 Polish elections which brought a real democracy to Poland!
You get to learn this and much more through a highly interactive and thoughtfully curated exhibition. Take your time, can take a whole half day to get through it all.

Excellent museum, I recommend the audio tour where most of the information is best captured and summarized. In the end I felt closer to my fellow European brothers, the Poles.

It is a multimedia deep dive into post World War II Poland and the Solidarity movement, with hints towards the rest of the Eastern Bloc countries and the rest of the world.

Starting in the shipyard of Gdansk, right where the museum is placed, an overview of the first strike of Solidarity is captivating and detailed.

All aspects of Polish society and their yearning for freedom are highlighted, during periods of strikes, a military junta and brotherhood found through faith via "their" Pope, John Paul II.

The significance of figures, like Lech Walesa in particular, who struggle for a brighter future, we can only support and have hope for a united Europe and world. Creating a path towards freedom and solidarity for all.
